solution.text:
Let \(\angle B\) be x
Then, \(\angle A\) will be 4x
\(\angle C\) = \(_{k}_^{\circ}\)
We know that the sum of all angles of triangle is \(180^{\circ}\).
i.e., \(\angle A + \angle B + \angle C = 180^{\circ}\)
i.e., \(\angle A + \angle B + _{k}_^{\circ} = 180^{\circ}\)
i.e., \(\angle A + \angle B = 180^{\circ}-_{k}_^{\circ}\)
i.e., \(\angle A + \angle B = _{{180-k}}_^{\circ}\)
i.e., \(4x + x = _{{180-k}}_^{\circ}\)
i.e., \(5x = _{{180-k}}_^{\circ}\)
i.e., \(x = _{{trunc((180-Decimal(k))/5,2)}}_^{\circ}\)
Therefore \(\angle B = _{{trunc((180-Decimal(k))/5,2)}}_^{\circ}\)
And, \(\angle A = _{{trunc(((180-Decimal(k))/5)*4,2)}}_^{\circ}\)

content.text:
In a triangle \(\angle C\) is \(_{k}_^{\circ}\) and \(\angle A \) is 4 times of \(\angle B\).
Find \(\angle A \) and \(\angle B\).
